overview.winter_access: Yellowstone National Park is primarily accessible via snowmobile and snow coach from mid-December through mid-March. Roads close to cars in late fall and reopen to wheeled traffic in spring. Winter access to interior areas like Old Faithful and Canyon is only possible via guided tours from gateway towns.
entry_points: Cody, WY (via East Entrance with guide)
Jackson, WY (via South Entrance with guide)
vehicle_types: Guided Snowmobiles (must be rented outside park)
Snow Coaches (heated, high-clearance vehicles with treads)
overview.permits: Snowmobile tours inside the park must be commercially guided unless part of the very limited non-commercial lottery system (OSV program).

best_winter_travel_routes.Old Faithful: Accessible via snowmobile and snowcoach from West Yellowstone and South Entrance.
best_winter_travel_routes.Canyon Village: Reachable via guided tours from West Yellowstone and special overnight snowcoach trips.
best_winter_travel_routes.Mammoth: Accessible by car year-round from Gardiner; only interior village open to vehicles in winter.
best_winter_travel_routes.Lamar Valley: Accessible by car year-round via Gardiner and Cooke City through the Northeast Entrance Road (plowed in winter).

details: Allows a limited number of private parties to enter the park on snowmobiles without a commercial guide.
Lottery opens in August each year through recreation.gov.
Winners receive one permit per day per group, valid for up to 5 snowmobiles.
Participants must complete an online safety certification course.
Permits are only valid from mid-December to mid-March and require strict adherence to park rules.

winter_packing_checklist: DOT-approved snowmobile helmet (usually provided by outfitter)
Insulated snowmobile suit or ski jacket/pants
Glove liners + insulated gloves or mittens
Sunscreen and lip balm (winter sun is intense)
Camera with extra batteries (cold drains battery life)
Park entrance pass or confirmation (provided by outfitter if guided)
